prompt: In 400-600 words, explain how stereotypes influence how people perceive and judge others. Discuss the psychological processes involved (e.g., schema theory, implicit bias, confirmation bias) and provide real-world or hypothetical examples. Your writing should be structured as a formal academic essay with clear arguments and APA-style referencing.

criteria.name: Introduction & Thesis
criteria.description: Effectiveness of the introduction and clarity of thesis statement.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Captivating introduction clearly sets the topic and includes a focused, insightful thesis that previews key points.
performance_descriptors.good: Clear introduction with a relevant thesis that previews the essays structure.
performance_descriptors.average: Introduction and thesis are present but lack clarity or specificity.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Introduction is vague and thesis is underdeveloped or hard to identify.
performance_descriptors.poor: Introduction is missing or off-topic; thesis is absent.

criteria.name: Use of Psychological Theory
criteria.description: Application and understanding of relevant psychological concepts.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Demonstrates mastery of psychological concepts (e.g., schema, stereotype formation, implicit cognition) with accurate and nuanced explanation.
performance_descriptors.good: Accurately uses theories with mostly clear explanation; one or two small gaps or simplifications.
performance_descriptors.average: Uses appropriate concepts but with limited explanation or partial misunderstandings.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Mentions theory but shows limited understanding or contains factual errors.
performance_descriptors.poor: Misunderstands or omits psychological theories entirely.

criteria.name: Application & Examples
criteria.description: Use of real-world or hypothetical examples to illustrate concepts.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Provides rich, relevant real-world or hypothetical examples that clearly illustrate the psychological concepts.
performance_descriptors.good: Good examples used with generally effective connections to the topic.
performance_descriptors.average: Examples are somewhat relevant but lack depth or clarity in linking to theory.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Vague or underdeveloped examples; weak connection to psychological ideas.
performance_descriptors.poor: No examples provided, or examples are irrelevant or incorrect.

criteria.name: Development of Argument
criteria.description: Clarity, structure, and critical thinking in the argument.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Ideas are fully developed, well-reasoned, and demonstrate critical thinking and synthesis.
performance_descriptors.good: Points are logical and clear, with mostly solid development of argument.
performance_descriptors.average: Argument is understandable but may be shallow or loosely structured.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Argument is weakly developed, repetitive, or missing logical links.
performance_descriptors.poor: No clear argument; content is confusing, unfocused, or incoherent.

criteria.name: Conclusion
criteria.description: Effectiveness of the closing paragraph in reinforcing ideas.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Strong conclusion that reinforces the thesis and leaves a lasting impression; fully wraps up essay.
performance_descriptors.good: Conclusion restates the thesis clearly and provides closure.
performance_descriptors.average: Conclusion is present but somewhat vague or mechanical.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Conclusion is rushed or doesn't reinforce main points effectively.

criteria.name: Language, Structure & Style
criteria.description: Grammar, tone, transitions, and clarity of writing.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Academic language is fluent and sophisticated; grammar, transitions, and paragraphing are nearly flawless.
performance_descriptors.good: Mostly formal tone and clear writing; few minor errors in grammar or structure.
performance_descriptors.average: Language is readable but inconsistently academic; some grammar or flow issues.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Writing lacks clarity or formality; multiple grammar or cohesion issues.
performance_descriptors.poor: Writing is unclear, informal, and riddled with errors that hinder understanding.

criteria.name: APA Referencing
criteria.description: Accuracy of APA-style citation and source usage.

performance_descriptors.excellent: APA guidelines followed precisely with all sources properly cited and referenced.
performance_descriptors.good: Minor APA errors; all required sources are cited.
performance_descriptors.average: Some issues with APA formatting or missing a citation.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Several APA formatting issues; some sources not cited.
performance_descriptors.poor: No citations provided or APA format not attempted.

key_points: Define stereotypes as cognitive schemas used to simplify social information.
Explain how schema theory supports stereotype activation and perception filtering.
Discuss implicit bias and how automatic associations can guide judgement unconsciously.
Explain confirmation bias as a mechanism that sustains existing stereotypes.
Provide real-world examples, such as racial profiling or workplace bias.
Use theories and research evidence to explain how stereotypes influence behaviour and perception.
Organize the essay with a clear thesis, logical argument structure, and academic language.
Cite all sources in APA style throughout the essay.
llm_questions: What is schema theory and how does it relate to stereotypes?
What is the difference between implicit bias and explicit bias?
How does confirmation bias reinforce stereotypes in everyday thinking?
Can you give real-world examples of how stereotypes influence judgment?
What psychological research supports the impact of stereotypes on perception?
How do I structure a formal academic essay in psychology?
Can you help write an introduction and thesis for this topic?
What are some credible sources I can cite about implicit bias and social cognition?
